reviewText:
Plagued by a sudden and insatiable urge to investigate a mysterious, far away sawmill in a remote, Italian countryside, a man tries to uncover the source of his fevered visions and sense of familiarity with a place he has no recollection of ever visiting, despite evidence to the contrary. His search leads him to unearth a gruesome history of the abandoned dwelling and its past inhabitants, and in particular to the story of Anna, a woman who seems to somehow be at the heart of it all. But to what end?

A first person horror game set almost entirely within a single, modestly sized building, players are tasked with solving puzzles to both progress exploration and to reveal the story related to each room and/or the part the items involved in each puzzle played in past events. But the deeper you delve into the mystery, the more your sanity and reality are called into question as the world begins to change around you and conspire against your efforts. Presentation is stunning as the visuals, sound and overall design are the beating heart around which this games revolves and reason enough to play it through from start to finish.

UI is largely intuitive but can confound on occasion as there's no explanation of its more intricate workings necessary for fully uncovering the story. In fact, that probably also sums up just about every aspect of the gameplay here. Satisfying and frustrating in equal measure, for every part of the game that there is to enjoy, there's also as many flaws as the puzzles and story become increasingly convoluted towards its conclusion. Since quite a few of the puzzles are based around performing rites and rituals, it means the player has no natural process of logic or intelligence to apply to the solution, but instead must pick up on the clues or directions provided by the game, which at times can prove annoyingly obtuse.

But don't let that stop you. Despite its shortcomings (one of the biggest of which is the unneccesary DRM which requires that you create an account with Kalypso Media in order to run the game. A process that feels incredibly archaic at this stage in our chosen pastime), that still doesn't stop it from being a worthwhile and gratifying experience, for nothing else if not for providing one of the singular most startling scares I've had in a game to date (mind how you go in the artisan room!). Anna - Extended Edition also includes the original game released prior to the free update which overhauled a massive amount of the game to include a myriad of new content and greatly expands upon the story and its surrounding lore. In comparion, the extended edition makes the original seem like a skeleton without its flesh and really should only be played after finishing the latest version just to see how far the game has come and how much effort developer Dreampainters went to in order to craft an experience that stays with you long after the credits have finished rolling.

reviewText:
This game is quite disturbing, that's the first thing I will say. Anna - Extended Edition is a challenging point and click type of game that nudges the survival horror genre a little. I mention survival horror mainly because it seems quite inspired by Amnesia - The Dark Descent, however it does not require you to run away and hide from monsters once in a while. The game does have a sanity meter, though, but other than that it continues down the puzzle road, mainly.

You start outside, in the yard of a house - a sawmill, and you suffer from amnesia. What's with all of the amnesia themed horror games these days? Putting that question aside, your first challenge begins. The house is locked, how do you get in? Ah, our first puzzle! The first of gazillions, crazy, disturbing and somewhat illogical puzzles! Although, I have to admit that the original game was worse in the 'illogical' part.

Once you get inside the horror starts. This game will mess with your mind. I found myself disturbed many times as I progressed through the game. There are several events that triggers randomly, different intuitions to unlock and combine, a lot of books to read and on top of that Anna has eight different endings! This of course boosts the replayability a lot, if you can stomach going through the game several times.

Visually, it's decent. It's not the prettiest one in the bunch, but it has the atmosphere nailed. Graphics are not important when it comes to psychological mind*bleep* games, in my opinion. The sound quality is somewhat lacking at times and there are occasional frame rate issues, sadly. It's not a flawless game but if you can close your eyes to various bugs then you won't have a problem playing the it, despite its somewhat awkward controls.

All in all, I was pleasantly surprised by the game but then again I knew nothing about it so I had no expectations when I first started playing it. I will admit that it's not for 'everyone' and it's definitely not a game for the youngest gamers out there. If you'd like to experience a twisted story then look no further - Anna is quite effed up in terms of story. It's a bit like The Cat Lady - you really have no damn clue about what's going on, which will generate a numerous of WTF?!"s as you continue deeper into the secrets of that abandoned house."

Anna is an amazing, yet disturbing experience with a unique and engaging story. The game seems relatively tame when starting in the lush green yard of an abandoned house that doesn't look all that sinister from the outside. However, once gaining access to the inside, things start to unfold that maybe you really didn't want to see in the first place. There a many different puzzles to be solved, some requiring a fair amount of reading various notes and books for the necessary clues and information. The music is fabulous and definitely one of the brightest spots in the game and the supernatural events will test your sanity. There are even several different possible endings adding some replayability.

I did find Anna to be a little on the difficult side as far as figuring out what items were used for what purpose mostly because there are a lot of different items and sometimes the solutions were far from obvious. Then there are the intuitions which I didn't understand at all without finally reading a guide. It also has an intrusive Kalypso DRM installed requiring an e-mail account and password.

Everything told, Anna is definitely a worthwhile chilling adventure that is sure to have you second guessing yourself.

Amid a string of mediocre releases, large franchises being retooled into more action oriented romps and the trend to make games more accessible, triple A survival horror games seem to be on the ropes. Fans of the genre hold out for the triumphant return of limited supplies, vulnerable protagonists, dark and moody atmosphere, and freakish creatures. Where there is a demand someone will inevitably step up with a supply. Dreampainters has stepped forward with a modest entry in the horror game genre. It isn't a traditional survival horror title but it does promise scares and chills. With such strong games like Amnesia helping to scratch the survival horror itch would seem reasonable that Anna could deliver, right?

Anna begins with your nameless, faceless, voiceless character in front of a sawmill explaining that he was drawn to its location. Your character is actually a teacher on leave of absence due to debilitating headaches. He finds some photos among his belongings that show him at the sawmill despite the fact that he remembers none of this. Players can only obtain this information if they bother to read the faux notebook contained in the extras folder of the game folder. The narrative is sparse—almost nonexistent really. While the esoteric nature of the story is intended to elicit curiosity it never offers a solid enough foundation to pique your interest. Not even establishing who your character is or what is motivating him in the game itself ensures that you remain distant from the events in Anna.

Anna plays as a first person point and click adventure game. You meander around the game's environments picking up and examining objects in an effort to solve some of the most obtuse and absurd puzzles in video game history. It should be noted that ridiculous puzzles are not exactly uncommon in adventure games but they usually include hints or cues that provide the necessary hints to complete them. Anna, however eschews such formalities, instead forcing the player to combine random items and blindly guess what is necessary to solve the puzzle at hand. On top of this even when the puzzles do make some sense they are often undermined by pixel hunting. It makes sense that you would use your lighter to light the stove but attempting to use the lighter on the kindling in the stove will not provide the expected results. Using your lighter on the stove on the other hand will... It compounds the frustration and makes playing Anna tantamount to an act of masochism.

Anna also blunders by failing to offer a credible threat. What is a horror game without some sort of impending doom? There is no way to fail Anna. The “horror” in this game comes from witnessing supernatural events which are rarely effective. They range from laughable (a card board cutout looking character blanketed in PSX era black particle effects) to mildly creepy (a mask whose eyes follow you around the room before appearing as a ghostly apparition behind the character). Anna doesn't do everything wrong though when it comes to effects and atmosphere. Upon making progress and revisiting some areas in the game you will notice that they are changed around. This reduces the tedium in backtracking as well as offering the occasional unsettling imagery. Messages will also appear on the walls and slowly fade away. It's in these brief moments that Anna shines but it isn't long before it's luster tarnishes.

reviewText:
Anna is one of those first person exploration games that does not have a protagonist with an array of weapons; there are no boss battles, no multiplayer and no high-budget cutscenes connecting one stage to another. It does not mean that it is a bad thing. Quite the contrary - considering its low budget nature Anna is quite a beautiful game; its sound and music are equally good.

The story revolves around a professor who is haunted by an image in his dreams - a sawmill that is constantly calling him. He finally decides to set out and seek out the answer - Anna seems to be the name of the woman calling him and while the house is surrounded by a forest and spacious, green garden upon entering the game's tone immediately changes to something much, much darker. Our hero begins to hear more voices and here the game focuses on puzzle solving till the very end.

While the game is similar to a certain degree to Amnesia its psychological / horror nature is very far from it. There are some jump scares here and there but those of you already familiar with Amnesia may find these quite boring. However, the puzzles are interesting and the many books we find in the house give us the background of an interesting story. As for the puzzles: it is difficult to know sometimes what to do - the inventory can easily become filled with items and objects can be used not just with our surroundings but their combination is a must, too.

The Extended Edition is an upgrade the game received and the only version of the game that can be purchased. One of the new concepts introduced was the sanity meter - again, something reminiscent of Amnesia. Still, while wandering aimlessly and not knowing what to do I could not manage to completely go insane. I understand it would have given an extra ending (the game has 8 different endings, by the way).

Anna is a bit rough around the edges - its narrative is not the best and the puzzles could have been a bit easier. The sanity meter is good but as we cannot die we do not really have a sense of threat while searching for Anna in the abandoned household. reviewText:
Full disclaimer: I did not finish this game. I really really really wanted to like this game. Really truly. However it has some really serious flaws that made me want to stop playing. So I did.

First off, the atmosphere and ambiance in this game are phenomenal. It is very immersive and beautiful to look at. The sound design is smart, the visuals are stunning. The way in which the story is told is very nice, very intriguing, and really weaves an interesting world for the player. The horror is excellent. Very few games have made me jump and just physically react like some of the scares in this game have.

However, despite all it has in it's favor, it has some serious issues that make actually playing the game exceptionally frustrating. Perhaps the biggest offender, and probably what gets harped on the most, is how completely obtuse and irrationally difficult many of the puzzles are. You will carry items around with you for most of the game without ever having a use for them. Your inventory will be so waterlogged with pointless items that you'll find yourself trying every possible combination of items on a puzzle, no matter how illogical, and when you finally think you've got a solution that makes sense, the game says no, that's not the right answer, continue scavenging every square inch of the house for that one item you missed in a dark corner. Additionally, death is very unforgiving. Granted I got through half the game without dying, but when you do, you get the bad ending, and if you want to continue have to go back to your last (manual) save. You do not make a game with perma-death and no checkpoints, this is not 1995, I don't want to sound entitled but I really do feel like that is just basic game design common sense. And on the topic of death, every time you see a scary event, you lose health. This might be okay if there were more ways to restore your health, but there are not. And in a horror game, you kind of want to check out all the scary things. I mean, they're some of the strongest design points of the game, I'd be loathe to run away from any of them. But no, they damage you, and lead to death, so you should avoid these smart well-made scenes that really make the game experience.

This game had so much potential. I am very disappointed that it didn't live up to it.
4/10

reviewText:
This review will be about Anna - Extended Edition. I also played the original version tho im not going to say anything about it. I mean why play the old version when you can play the updated and polished one?

Story 8/10

The story revolves around a man with amnesia who dreams about an old sawmill in the mountains and a woman he can't forgot - Anna. To find his lost memories, the reason why he lost them and the true identity of Anna, he finds himself at this place again. In order to do so, he's got to solve misterys/puzzles and keep his sanity while witnessing a lot of supernatural phenomena to get his way through all the rooms in the sawmill to eventually find out the truth.

Everything will be told to you through voices you hear throughout the game, books you'll find and read, notes the protagonist will make about certain things and with your own intuition. The Extended Edition has 8 different endings which i'll not put on display here so don't worry about spoilers.
I enjoyed playing this game while discovering all the different endings and making conclusions on what exactly happend there. The story is not made that easy so you don't get bored after the first time playing it because you already know whats going to happen, but also not that difficult that you can#t understand everything. You will have a great time playing this gem if you pay attention and take your time to read certain books/notes you find throughout the game, because this game is certainly not something you can rush through and expect to understand everything. I enjoyed the story and everything around it and can only recommend it.

Gameplay 9/10

You see everything from the 1st person view, you have to explore the area and find clues and objects to solve puzzles/riddles in order to progress in the story(If you played something like Amnesia you will have a better image of what i mean). Theres no healthbar in the game so you basically can't die, but theres a bar that shows you your sanity.
Meaning if you witness to many harmfull events, the game will end with a rather unsatisfying ending, depending on how far you got.[/i]

the gameplay is easy to understand so nothing really there to confuse you. The only thing i would have to mention is that in the beginning the controls might feel a bit off when you are trying to use the objects you found and when you are trying to interact with your enviroment, but that will go away after playing for a bit so no serious problem. Only bad thing i would have to mention is that sometimes the phenomena you witness are bugged. Well leaving the 2 buggs i witnessed aside the game has a solid, simple gameplay.

Sound 6/10

Dialogs are voiced really good, everything is easy understandable and just fits the situations. Backgroundmusic and sound effects are not especially good or bad. The game also features different background music while exploring the sawmill.

Overall the music,dialogs sound effects are good. Nothing special that will be stuck in your head but im not going to use that as a negative point for the game. What i really didn't like is that you can easily notice when something is going to happen, because most of the time theres a change in music slightly before something happens. Personally i think that is the worst thing about this game since it takes away the fear, which..well.. should be in a horror game

Conclusion 7/10

Taking everything into account im giving this game a 7 out of 10. The story is enjoyable and interesting enough to make you feel like you want to know everything and get all the different endings to find the real truth. Gameplaywise there isn't much innovation but also nothing really bad to say about it.
All in all i had a great time playing this game, playing it multiple times to learn more about Anna and her story. Some of the phenomena scared me for good the first time and some of them even for the second and third time :D. I can really recommend this game for people who like horror point&click adventure games. But don't expect the great horror, if you do, choose something else because this game is focused more on revealing the good story with some nice scare-jumps to push up the mood of the game a bit.

reviewText:
Anna is a great first-person puzzle / adventure that perked my interest in the genre.

The basic story involves exploring a house, and getting to the dark secrets held deep within its maze of puzzles. Through the use of books and notes found in the game, we learn more about the characters involved in what happened here, come to our own conclusions. The whole environment has a surreal feel about it, at times beautiful, other times chilling, or supernatural. At its heart it is a tale about obsession, the cult of the Sacred Feminine, and worshipping a woman like a goddess.

Gameplay involves picking up items and figuring out what to do with them, made more interesting by the creepy ambience and the feeling you are being watched. The mask is definitely right up there as a spine-tingler, and I'm not talking about just how ugly it is. I found myself stuck at least two or three times, so if you don't run to a walthrough at the drop of a hat it is pretty easy to rack up the gameplay hours trying to figure out what to do next. Moments like these are ideal for if you're eating breakfast or having a cup of coffee.

Starting the game may seem dull - this is because you begin the game outside the house. Don't let this fool you. It can be pretty, or pretty boring depending on your mood. Once you get inside things start to get interesting. Imagery gets a bit busier - you have a lot more things to look at compared to the open spaces of outside. In the latter half of the game the supernatural events kick in to high gear and things really start to get interesting.

Want to know more? I don't want to spoil it for you, so you better get the game and find out for yourself. It may be short (depending on how fast you do the puzzles), but I found it an enjoyable break between longer games. It has its scary moments but these aren't too bad - you won't quit playing out of fear at any rate.

Other points to note: I had no problems getting the game to run on Windows 7, I don't even remember the DRM that others have mentioned. Controls are not the best, granted - but I didn't have any game-breaking bugs.

reviewText:
Anna, at least I found, is a pretty confusing mess of a game that doesn’t really know what it is trying to do. At first, it seems like a very cut-and-dry Unity based adventure game (think Gone Home, or Slenderman for its control scheme/layout/control feel). As supposed to those games, however, there is a much lighter tone (at least at first), but once you pass the first true puzzle of the game, the whole mood changes. Gone is the bright, beautiful scenery, replaced with a drab, plain shack essentially. Once in the new setting, more horror based elements start to present them. These aren’t necessarily fear-inducing (which is what I believe this style of game is commonly used for), instead it just has an overall creepy vibe. The creepy vibe is sometimes subdued by the absurdity of the scares at some points (“walk into a room, ooooh there’s blood on the wall! Isn’t that scary?!”). Sometimes, they do have a really effective moment (there is one puzzle I can recall upon completion, a floating mask will follow you around, with the sounds of muffled breathing coming from behind you until you turn around), but these moments are far and few between, and not enough to set the mood.

Although these horror elements are going on, there is very soft and relaxing guitar music playing, which partially breaks the immersion with the game. There is also never really any sense of danger (for one, you can’t die, but this is common in these sorts of games). I found there was always just a one off scare, then more relaxing music and adventure-esque puzzles (The first puzzle involves putting two pieces of a mirror shard in an eye hole in the wall, using a pine cone to make an iris, burning said pinecone to “burn the left side of the door to reveal a keyhole (I never gathered this occurred when playing)”, then putting out the eye with a filled canteen).

In terms of the story, it follows a person being drawn to the cabin by a mysterious voice to be revealed as “Anna.” Exploring through the game shows that she was an ancient goddess that would lure men into worshiping her, then killing for her pleasure (very similar in narrative to the ancient cult of Diana of Italian mythos). In terms of the endings, they tend to go against the norm that each ending gets progressively worse and worse for the main character as it goes on (the happier ending is the easiest).

In conclusion, the game seems to be slightly confused in terms of what it is trying to do. The story was very horror-esque, but at no point did it really feel like it was truly immersive into this role. The music (although nice) didn’t really fit into this game, as well as the different scare tatics implemented.  Overall, I cannot recommend this game for many. If you are a fan of much slower horror games, maybe give this a play (it’s not very long either, clocking in at about 3-4 hours), but as a general note, I cannot recommend the game.

reviewText:
I was raised on puzzle games, growing up with Myst, Adventure Co., and Lovecraft, so I was hopeful about this game. But I must say that it was wholly disappointing and I really had to force myself to finish it. Everything that I will briefly mention is negative, unfortunately.

It was not as beautiful as I had hoped, and I found the levels to be mostly dark and ugly. The music was pleasant enough, but often seemed to clash with what was actually occurring. The story itself was very ugly. Be prepared to not only read about but also participate in pagan rituals (and not really have a clear idea of why you’re having to do them). I felt very, very uncomfortable doing these. Finding out who the characters are is the main goal of the game, but there really isn’t any personal connection to the characters, and no real motivation to want to know them. They are just a mystery. The puzzles are ambiguous and I found that it often became an inventory click-fest. The inventory I found to be one of the biggest irritants. There were about three pages of inventory items, half of them red-herrings and dead ends, and I was constantly scrolling back and forth, equipping and unequipping items, and waiting for the game to load while doing so. That became quite tedious, as did having to read and reread the slow-loading item descriptions that may or may not change the second and third time you click on an item. The text itself I found to be the most irritating part of all. Generally I love to go around collecting books and letters. In this game, I cringed every time I found a book, knowing I would have to read it. The books were generally a mash of useless, repetitive, uninteresting words that you nevertheless had to read through to find a recipe for some puzzle. Not only are they in a rather difficult font to read, the attempts at sounding archaic—filtered through a poor translation—were extremely distracting and unpleasant.

The one thing I appreciated was the idea of mouse movement being a sort of feedback for the reactions of the player. However, all that means is that looking around when events are happening will get you killed. In other words, whenever something interesting happens, you are supposed to freeze and look at a wall (I guess). That really isn’t fun. Since a sanity meter was never mentioned, to me this just did not make any sense in the context it was used, and I would have appreciated being told why I was dying.

I love scary games with great story. I did not find this game to be at all frightening. It was mostly just uncomfortable and I felt no investment in the characters or their progress in the game. I hate to give such a bad review for a genre I really enjoy, but I would suggest avoiding this game, especially if you are not particularly interested in pagan deities, blood rituals, and fertility cults.

I've invested a little less than half an hour into this game after it became abundantly clear that this is not something I can enjoy. I love a good adventure game and after playing Amnesia, I've bought this game -thankfully on a sale- to satisfy my urge for more scary, adventure-y goodness.  Unfortunately I was disappointed.

The game starts with asking you to create a Kalypso user account (which is essentially an extra layer of unneccesary DRM); something we don't need nor will probably ever use. It is noted on the Store page for the title however, so buyers beware.

In the game, your character moves in a fashion that I could only call unnatural. I don't know if it is due to the FOV or something else, but I felt literally nauseated after playing for 15 minutes. I normally don't get motion sickness from first-person games, especially ones with a relatively slower movement speed, like this one. But since I've spent very little time with the title I can't tell if its a fluke or not.

The user interface is horrible. It simply is badly designed, so much so that I had to check if it was a console port or something(It isn't). It is completely counter-intuitive, hard to navigate and use. In an adventure game, this is unacceptable. The options menu is very barebones, it feels like the developers made it as an afterthought, quite reminiscent of a bad port instead of the PC exclusive title that we have.

The puzzles are very contrived and illogical(unlike say, Monkey Island, it really doesn't have any redeeming qualities, such as being humorous). By the time I managed to go into the house(you start outside at the beggining) I've already lost my interest in the game.  I don't care  if the game opens up or gets very scary afterwards, I simply didn't see any reason to stick with it any longer.

The game looks pretty and it ran on my machine smoothly without any problems. I haven't encountered any bugs. The sound assets used were quite good.

All in all, the game might get better later on, for all I know. But I didn't want to struggle with the bad UI and the uninspired puzzles to get to the meat. I uninstalled the title immediately after exiting it. I would recommend the prospective buyer to watch a gameplay video so that they can decide if the problems I report are relevant to them.

If you're a fan of the genre, you might want to pick it up at a sale. But I can not, in good conscience, recommend this game.

Only the people who play it on Windows have to sign in to Kalypso though, so if you don't play on windows, that won't affect you.

Overall, I wouldn't recommend the game, especially at full price, unless you like confusing tasks and predictable stories.

reviewText:
I've invested a little less than half an hour into this game after it became abundantly clear that this is not something I can enjoy. I love a good adventure game and after playing Amnesia, I've bought this game -thankfully on a sale- to satisfy my urge for more scary, adventure-y goodness.  Unfortunately I was disappointed.

The game starts with asking you to create a Kalypso user account (which is essentially an extra layer of unneccesary DRM); something we don't need nor will probably ever use. It is noted on the Store page for the title however, so buyers beware.

In the game, your character moves in a fashion that I could only call unnatural. I don't know if it is due to the FOV or something else, but I felt literally nauseated after playing for 15 minutes. I normally don't get motion sickness from first-person games, especially ones with a relatively slower movement speed, like this one. But since I've spent very little time with the title I can't tell if its a fluke or not.

The user interface is horrible. It simply is badly designed, so much so that I had to check if it was a console port or something(It isn't). It is completely counter-intuitive, hard to navigate and use. In an adventure game, this is unacceptable. The options menu is very barebones, it feels like the developers made it as an afterthought, quite reminiscent of a bad port instead of the PC exclusive title that we have.

The puzzles are very contrived and illogical(unlike say, Monkey Island, it really doesn't have any redeeming qualities, such as being humorous). By the time I managed to go into the house(you start outside at the beggining) I've already lost my interest in the game.  I don't care  if the game opens up or gets very scary afterwards, I simply didn't see any reason to stick with it any longer.

The game looks pretty and it ran on my machine smoothly without any problems. I haven't encountered any bugs. The sound assets used were quite good.

All in all, the game might get better later on, for all I know. But I didn't want to struggle with the bad UI and the uninspired puzzles to get to the meat. I uninstalled the title immediately after exiting it. I would recommend the prospective buyer to watch a gameplay video so that they can decide if the problems I report are relevant to them.

If you're a fan of the genre, you might want to pick it up at a sale. But I can not, in good conscience, recommend this game.

Ok, the game is not a masterpiece, but the story is nice and the gameplay is addictive. I found it worth playing.

reviewText:
I will never, ever a huge fan first-person games. They give me headaches, I find it ridiculously hard to keep the controls still and focused. I just really dislike them. However, Anna managed it masterfully and I actually found it beneficial for once.

Now I will agreee with some of the others that the puzzles in this game can be kind of ridiculous. THey can be pretty hard and you're not really given much to guide you in solving them. There was one point in the game where you have to start putting certain information that you collected together and I honestly only found out through glancing at a guide. I either missed it being hinted at in the game or it really wasn't there.

There's also a fair amount of backtracking that got annoying sometimes though it was understandable giving how self-contained the playing field was. But towards the end there was one point when I had to keep going up to the attic and down and into this room and out of this room. And sometimes it's hard to interact with the objects or tell if you grabbed something.

But I still worked my way through it because it was intriguing and I wanted to know the rest of the story. I found myself getting pretty immersed in it from the beginning. I found myself wanting to explore everything in the house and actually taking my time to read everything that I had picked up. I do wish the beginning part when you're outside the cabin was a little bit longer because it's such a big contrast to the dark, dreary, and sometimes bloody inside of the cabin but I don't think the game suffered from the that.

And the scares! The scares were just awesome. They were very rarely in your face scares and it was the subtle nature of them that made it frightened. You'd see things going on at the edge of your screen and you'd turn around and notice something weird happening or that something in the scene had changed. It was never extremely frightening but always really creepy which is why I really enjoyed playing this game.

reviewText:
When I first booted up this game my expectations sat somewhere between one of those dreadful mobile hidden object games and Amnesia the Incompetent Descent. Suffice to say I had no idea what this game was.

Though a bit rough on the eyes, Anna is a surprisingly enjoyable puzzle adventure game. Though I never played them as a child, I imagine this game would be vaguely nostalgic to those who grew up addicted to the likes of Myst and the spin-offs that arose from it's success.

In Anna you explore a world in the first person view, while solving puzzles in a classic, retro style point and click fashion. Luckily as far as I have seen, there is no absurd Sierra logic behind the item combinations.

Driving the gameplay forward is an underlying narrative that's a bit of a mix between horror and psychosis with some supernatural sprinkled on top for good measure. I can't say that I have too strong of an understanding of the plot thus far, but I'm interested none the less.

Anna - Extended Edition review:

Anna is a spooky as hell game, it's not much more than a point-and-click adventure game, yet it is so much more than a point-and-click adventure game. You play an 'amnesiac' who is drawn to an old abandoned sawmill, where some really disturbing events happened and you need to discover who you are and why this 'Anna' calls to you. The main gameplay mechanism is - pick up items and combine/use items on things in the environment to progress the story. I found that some of the puzzles were kind of absurd, like use a stick to smash through a concrete slab, but for the most part they are fairly consistent to the world. You will run into puzzles that you might think are completely absurd, mostly the ones dealing with occult rituals, but once you know the story and can decipher the metaphors everything begins to connect. This is what I found most entrancing about this game and it kept me thinking about the story even throughout the day.

Now, I have not yet unlocked the 'True Ending' yet, so I still don't even know everything about the story. But I have received the 'Good Ending' and I am not going to spoil anything, but once you understand the ending, it really is a, holy ♥♥♥♥"

reviewText:
Anna is wonderful little atmospheric horror and puzzle game that keeps you thinking about its story well past its conclusion.

The puzzles gradually increase in difficulty, starting off relatively logical until the end where they become, at times, truly some of the most bizarre events of any game. Though they can all be completed using the increasingly vague hints given throughout the story in the form of old texts, many players will turn to a guide for at least some because some will truly leave you asking what the hell you actually just did.

However, do not let the puzzles stop you from experiencing the best part of the game: its story. Drawing on various folk legends and the Pagan religion, as well as having multiple endings, the story will have you thinking about it and drawing connections well past the end. It's very easy to miss parts and multiple play throughs are required to do everything, giving it great replay value.

Finally the graphics and audio are absolutely gorgeous and serve their purpose of creating an incredibly creepy , surreal atmosphere throughout the game. Although some audio and lightning glitches are present, they did not detract from the overall experience very much.

While it may not be worth the full $10 to some, it is certainly worth its sale prices and has become one of the most intriquing games I've played because of its elements. Certainly not for everyone, but well worth a try if you get the chance.

Weird, Glitchy, and Confusing.

A glitch I ran into was that I was able to force a door open via physics manipulation (just grabbing the locked door and spazzing out with the mouse basically on numberous points) that was magically sealed and that I was not supposed to be able to open until a puzzle was finished.

This big of a glitch makes me thing there are likely more software related issues, as on the steam forums many complain about unstable performance. But my experience was that game ran fine at most times with any lack of performance possibly my hardware setup.

Graphically the game looks good. But its a very very small scope type of game, but it looks nice and isn't hard to run.

Its most like one of those DOS text adventure or later on when point and click type of adventure games came on. But unfortunately like some of them this game can be very confusing.  Eventually puzzles can amount to just randomly clicking on stuff until you get the right combo which is just a waste of time. At points some elements were really interesting in the puzzles, but more often than not it just made no sense or was illogical and confusing.  The books do help some but they only give you an inkling and the tips system if your stuck but have an idea of what you have to do is next to useless.

The seemingly random events such as stuff popping up or happening was interesting. And for the most part good. Look at something only to look away and back and its moved or gone. Gives a very creepy feeling that you are not safe and the world around you is alive. Which alot of games falter at and end up with a static feeling enviroment. As you progress the game world changes around you.

The only problem is that puzzles are just anti-intuitive at times and just to much and thats pretty much all the gameplay. Just walking around and interacting with things that are apart of puzzles.

The story is spooky ghost sprittual stuff from what I can tell. But I didn't really get it.

If you want a confusing puzzle game where you pretty much have to google atleast some part of the puzzles or waste hours trying to figure them out then I suppose this maybe for you. Sure the game could possibly draw you in, but once your there your stuck at a puzzle while you want to adventure in a world unlike one your used to.

Something I think this game could have been really great with is some top notch narration for books, and other parts where there is onscreen text your intended to read. Also making the text in as small and biteable chunks as possible instead of a giant wall of text paragraph that the in game books are. This would make them less of a chore to read and with the narration it would be possibly pleasurable to listen to if was anything like Bastions narration.

reviewText:
I know it's been a long time since I wrote my previous review, but now I feel the review didn't describe the game enough.

Anna is a game where you explore clues and where you try to find a mysterious woman named...well...Anna.

Graphics:
The graphics are downright gorgeous. This is something where you can close your eyes and feel that you are in the atmosphere. While they seem beautiful at first in the first scene of the game, it goes down towards the mystery and the creepy, scary side.

Music:
While this game only has a few tracks, the music is beautifully well done with acoustic guitar, violin, and piano. This is the kinda music you want to listen to while you're getting into the game or relaxing and touches your soul.

Gameplay:
There are two versions of the game: Original and Extended. The Original is more simple than the extended. It just focuses on items and getting through the game. The Extended, however, is more complicated, as there are more places to explore, more types of items to explore, and decisions and explorations that can affect the ending of the game. The upside of the Extended is that the story goes deeper.

With the differences aside, there is some weirdness with some items of the game. You have to combine items you didn't expect that go together or used on something, or items that are well hidden. This can be a downside for simple players or people who don't wanna spend so much minutes on figuring stuff out.

Story:
The story goes into a sort of mystery and cultish feel with going back to some parts of the past. Yes, this game has some jumpscares, but in a perfect amount. I don't want to get into details, but the story is simply looking for a woman you can't get out of your head and you have an obsession. Not a crazy, sick obsession, but more of a desire just to be with the woman.

In conclusion:
Anna is one of those explorative, story gems that is a must have in your library and must be played. The graphics, music, and story melt perfectly into the pot that makes it a masterpiece. While the gameplay might be a bit annoying, the rest of the game will encourage you to delve further to solve the mystery.

reviewText:
I am torn with this game. I suppose I just couldn't get into it, but I will give this game credit where it is due : it is very creative and this ''Extented Edition'' is a vast upgrade over the original. It is also gorgeous and is a real work of art, so I REALLY recommend this game for anyone (like me) that believes games can be art. It is a very mature game, not for the faint of heart, and not for the easily bored.

It was also VERY freaky, and it just got freakier and freakier, to the point that I started to feel just as insane as the character I was playing. Yeah, you're not supposed to look directly at the freaky ♥♥♥♥ that pops up to scare you. You have a kind of insanity meter, and its game over if it runs out. You then get the bad ending, which was my ending. Couldn't finish the game you see, but that wasn't really the reason.

The reason I don't REALLY want to recommend this game, but I will anyway due to the aforementioned points, is the puzzles. They make little to no sense. The whole game is heavily cryptic, to the point of insanity... and I guess its kinda the point, but I couldn't even get passed the first area without a walkthrough, and I don't think that's a point in its favor. Yes, you'll sometimes find a few clues in the form of books as to what to do next, but they are vague at best, or seem to have no connection with anything at worst. I just went in circles, revisiting room after room after room (once I finally unlocked them), not understanding what to do until I finally saw too many hallucinations and it was over. I guess there's two words to describe this : beautiful... but weird. VERY WEIRD.

So, I am tempted to continue this game, but it is as a big freaky impassable wall of nonsensical puzzles, which only the metaphorical industrial drill of a walkthrough can penetrate, which kinda destroys the immersion it tries to create. And if you do get through, blood will spill out and you'll go insane, then its game over. That pretty much sums up my experience.

THUMBS UP FOR ARTSYNESS THOUGH. I will not replay this though. Give it a try... if you dare...

There is a health meter but the game is really not that clear on what injures you so losing health just feels arbitrary. Through the game you collect intuitions and offers no explanation as to what they are but you need to work this out to progress to the final endings. All these things do not mean I did not enjoy this game, the mystery and the story kept me wanting to carry on. So overall I am giving this a thumbs up, it is flawed but pull up a walkthrough and enjoy the atmosphere and story.

reviewText: Anna is a first-person adventure/horror game. What I liked most is the suspenseful atmosphere and the story. Game's setting changes drastically over a few stages: first you find yourself outside a wooden sawmill, observing as the sun glistens from a calmly running stream. You feel intrigued to get inside the house and learn of it's secrets. Once you're inside - it gets pretty spooky. You solve puzzles and trigger scripted and random events to progress in the story. The puzzles are satisfying but usualy don't make much sense and are not really intuitive. I had to look up a few playthroughs to solve some puzzles - couldn't come up with solutions myself. Once you reach a certain point in the story, the setting becomes really grim. With an unholy presence in the sawmill and ambient sounds that chill down your spine - the experience is quite satisfying even for a horror junkie. The game has multiple endings which adds some replay value. All in all, Anna is a decent game with some flaws regarding puzzles, but if you're up for the challenge and have plenty of spare time to come up somewhat ridiculous solutions to solve puzzles - get this game. 7/10

reviewText:
Anna - Extended Edition does psychological horror better than any title I have ever played.  The sound, music, narration, story, design - all these things are absolutely remarkable, and Anna should be played by anyone who wants to see how a game like this should be done.

Quite unfortunately, the entire game is left in ruins due to an insulting puzzle-solving mechanic.  If the other features build the perfect arc, all that's necessary is a keystone that'll just keep those things in place.  It doesn't exist, and worse, this was reportedly done on purpose.

You repeatedly pick up items that you'll never use.  Puzzles make no sense and worse, there's no effort for them to do so.  I tried my damndest to get through the game without a guide, but it's impossible.  Unless you plan to hammer away at this title for a solid month for hours on end each day, you will never figure out each puzzle.  Worse yet, there are multiple endings depending on how you play the game - and nothing is explained to you at any point.  There are useful guides online, but I'd imagine even THEY needed help before writing it, or they went into the game's code to make sense of it all.

The only way I can recommend Anna is with a guide.  There are some on Steam and you can find some on YouTube.  They are non-negotiable.  If you want to enjoy Anna, you have to abandon your sense of integrity when it comes to solving puzzles on your own and use a guide.  If you can accept this, Anna will give you a new understanding of how games should be made with regards to every other feature.

Specifically the horror.  This game, numerous times, sent chills down my entire body.  They started at my neck and spread throughout my body and to my arms and legs.  Yet, not once though was I afraid to continue.  I never thought I shouldn't do something because something's lurking around the corner.  This game does horror better than any other title.  It exists on a level above all others.  There are no jump-scares or smash cuts to scary images.  While I might react quickly to a zombie or monster in another game, in this there are no monsters.  The every-changing environment is enough to scare you.  One feature in particular is a visage of a woman made of wood that changes position and follows you.  It never attacks you, it's simply there.  Yet each time it appears in a place I don't expect, even if I was just looking there, it managed to get me almost every time.

For this reason alone, I recommend Anna.  Everything in the game is fantastic.  The one thing that is completely absent, and insultingly so by design, is sensible puzzle solving.  If you can stomach the fact that you'll need a guide from the onset, this title is thoroughly enjoyable.

reviewText:
Good psychological horror / puzzle adventure game - I don't want to give away any spoilers, but I will say that I had more frights in this game than even Amnesia TDD (well, maybe - Amnesia is damn good, you should definitely play it).

Remember - headphones should be up loud and the lgihts should be off - if you're not psyched out to get scared you're doing it wrong.

It's not a terribly long game - Steam reckons it only took me four hours to unlock the Truth ending, and some of that was walking around trying to find some object I had missed because it was right next to (and looked like part of) another much more interesting object (ye olde classic puzzle adventure game problem). On a positive note the game doesn't wait for you to make progress to decide to give you a scare, which nicely avoids the boredom problem that many adventure games have in that situation.

It's actually probably for the best that it wasn't any longer - like many psychological horror games the scares have less and less impact as you get more used to them. By the end of the game I wasn't jumping whenever XXXXXXXX happened any more, which makes me think the length was about right (although that was in my second sitting - I'd recommend playing through the whole thing in one sitting if you can).


Also, there are intuitions at the top of the inventory screen. I only mention this because I didn't notice until I was almost finished the whole game and it seems like they might have an influence on the ending.


One annoyance I had with the game was that some of the cutscenes are unskippable - including the expelled ending sequence which happens when you lose too much sanity. Unfortunaly at one point I had saved a game with almost no sanity left and I had to keep sitting through that ending and reloading over and over until I was able to make some progress before the game threw another random event at me.


One final warning - this game includes some 3rd party DRM. While it's far from the worst DRM scheme around it's still unwelcome - you will need to create an account with Kalypso before you can play.

I also had some technical issues with my controls (the camera spun by itself every 5 seconds), though it mysteriousely resolved itself after a few attempts to launch the game.

reviewText: Anna - Extended Edition is a unique and extremely creepy adventure game.  In fact, I thought that the audio and visuals were even more disturbing that the arguable more famous Amnesia.  The story is interesting and unfolds gradually as the player interacts with different puzzles and objects in an abandonded house, piecing together the mystery of what happened there.  There is no dialogue interactions in the game but the storytelling is well done without them.  The steam overlay, widescreen resolutions and steam achievements are supported but unfortunately the controller is not.  Anna's strength is also it's weakness, it is maddeningly difficult to figure out how to solve the puzzles.  In fact, this is a game that is nearly impossible to complete without the assistance of a walkthrough video.  However, the several possible endings based on the choices you make bring some replayability to the game that is often missing from adventure titles.  In all, Anna is a succesful but flawed entry into the genre and should be considered by anyone who enjoys a difficult adventure game.

reviewText: Despite the some of the special effects feeling a tad dated, I can honestly and with a straight face say that I have never reacted to a game like I reacted to this one. I can understand that many may not feel the same way upon playing, but my friend Skye can attest to the fact that I was yelling in shock and anxiety repeatedly while make my way through the game. The sound design is phenomenal in that often when you hear a sound there's nothing there...but sometimes there is...and it's that 1-in-10 moment that makes you jump out of your seat. The same principle is applied to the 'inhabitants' of the sawmill. These elements combine to create a living, unpredictable, and malevolent environment that continually surprises and engages you. My only criticisms extend to the occasionally insane difficulty and abstract nature of some of the puzzles, and the lack of explanation of the so-called 'intuitions', which, given how pivotal they are in regards to your experience, lack any in-game explanation as to their importance or function. The Extended Edition has many improvements over the original (longer game length, more puzzles, increased graphical quality) and, in my opinion, completely redeems the experience. 8.5/10.

As a person who has always been afraid of horror games, this game was quite the catch I needed to help me overcome that fear. There are no monsters like Amnesia or other horror games. It is purely puzzle-driven, with some psychological fear factors added into it. The scenery is beautiful, the music is wonderful as well, though at times it seems like it does not fit the atmosphere of the game. However, I think with how soft, and beautiful, the music is, adds to the atmosphere of the overall game.

Now, a couple of things I did not really like about this game. It felt WAY too short... Maybe even a little rushed at some parts. I feel there could be so much more done to this to help aid the story along and to add more to it. I also hated some of the puzzles. I had no idea what to do for some of them, and eventually had to give in and look up a guide. There are a couple of puzzles that give hints, but other than that, nothing. The controls are rather easy to remember. The inventory is another issue that I had. There were some items that were SO pointless to have that the end of the game, and even throughout the game.

Aside from the few cons and issues I had with this game, it definitely terrified me to play the first couple of times. I have played through it numerous times for different friends, all which have liked the ctual story. Personally, I would have to give this game a 7.5/10. There were some things that could be improved, but overall I think it was a very interesting, very plot-twisting game.

Anna is a mentally horrifying, horror adventure game that scared me ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥… I’m a wuss when it comes  to horror games so don’t take my word for it when I say this game is excellent…

You get a bunch of these types of games like Amnesia and Outlast, but games like those use a scary monster with a big mouth and twitchy or slow and sluggish movement to scare the living daylights out of you when it BURSTS through a wall or suddenly appears behind you..

Anna does what it does, very differently… It slowly builds tension and ever so slightly increases the eeriness of the environment and scares you using things like chairs and bursting steam pipes…
If you had to personify games like Outlast and Anna: Outlast would be a creepy old man with a knife staggeringly approaching you in a dark alley and no matter where you turn, that old man is there, staggeringly approaching. While Anna on the other hand is a woman, standing with her back towards you slowly turning around until you see half her face expecting the rest to be horribly maimed, but instead it’s a perfectly normal woman with a loving look in her eyes. Then you suddenly realize that the thing you should be running from is the big ♥♥♥♥ing wooden “mom-doll” slowly emerging from behind the woman, reaching for you with her branch arms…

I recommend this game for anyone into adventure and horror...

If you are into this subtle kind of horror this game is worth the time and money.

reviewText:
Anna is a first person adventure game involving the supernatural and psychological horrors held within an old mountain sawmill/home that has fallen into disrepair.  You play as an, apparently un-named, history professor who has been mysteriously drawn the sawmill by a strong feeling of deja vu when he finds pictures of the place in his closet, despite having no memory of the place.

When I watched the trailer on Steam I noticed that most of the objects in the game aren't even animated, and almost passed by this game because of it.  While it is true that there is almost no animation outside of physics objects, the mood and setup was all that's needed to emerse me into the game.  Also, because many of the objects are stationary, it led me to question whether the house is in fact haunted or if the man I was playing as was going insane.  It's obvious that this was an intentional choice as the game uses clever placement to ensure that you're not looking when certain objects move or materialize, which to be honest did make me jump a few times.

The story of what happened at the sawmill and the ways in which I was required to reveal it are also better than I expected. reviewText:
A great concept marred by bitterly pityful execution.

What starts out to be a promising logical puzzle horror adventure game turns out to be a completely irrational, illogical set of clicks and attempts by the player to try to guess what the developers intended to happen with little or no feedback at all. Even the in-game hints system is vague at best.

The controls for inventory and using items is very annoying and lacks fluidity. The forced walking speed is an annoyance, especially when there is a fair amount of backtracking throughout the game involved.

You also can not describe this title as a horror survival either, as its not possible to die.

Some nice touches of horror brushing through the gameplay but very weak and suspense is not sustained properly in-game, which causes the scares to be cheap jumps rather than actual in-your-head horror. Not very obvious but there are 3 different endings which is always a nice touch to implement into any game.

I'm a fan of this genre so its great to see games like this get developed and out into the commercial world, especially by independant developers but if unpolished titles like this were released out often the genre would be soon dead and forgotten.

Worth a couple of quid in the sale and you have an interest in horror type games, but avoid paying full whack.

reviewText:
Anna is... weird. But a pretty fun kind of weird. A bit slow at parts, but enjoyable on the whole.

The key things to bring along when playing Anna are observation and inference. There are a lot of puzzles whose required solutions are fairly subtly hidden, so you'll need to keep an eye out for objects and/or connections between things you've seen or found most of the time. This is made that much more important by how Anna takes a lot of different occult material and remixes it into its own pocket mythos, making any supernatural points of reference the player may have a bit less useful here.

Speaking of remixes, if you've played the non-Extended edition before, there are some new and remixed puzzles from the original version, so keep that in mind. Solutions have changed slightly, or at least, it felt as such. To be fair, it'd been a while since I finished Anna originally, so it could just be failures on my memory's part.

Despite its occasional drifts into the obtuse, Anna - Extended Edition is a fun, sometimes frustrating romp through lingering dread and ambient menace. The encapsulated nature of the story presents something different from most rehashed horror trope-fests and is worth trying, if only to get your brainmeats flexing for a bit.

If you want a taste of the game, here's a -really- old clip of me exploring the starting area in the original version. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oVfEaD8peUQ
